choices.text: Enter the gallery!

1100000.content: This photo was taken on a bridge famous for its so-called 'motor-cycle waterfall.' Every day after work, as tens of thousands of employees hit the streets, countless motor-cycle drivers take to the road. Motor-cycles and mopeds are extremely popular in TaiBei, creating an effect such that, on looking out over the roads, the myriad waves of cyclists give the illusion of one massive wave. As this tsunami of traffic makes its way over the bridge, and the steep descent on either side, it makes for a magnificent sight that attracts tourists from many countries.

choices.text: Explore the city.
Check out the TaiWan suburbia
Visit the local wildlife

1110000.content:
Before you look any more at the city, make sure you follow the house rules! 

 Signs like this can be found all over China and TaiWan. While catering to English speaking tourists through these thoughtfully placed signs, poor translations often lead to a few...misunderstandings. Warning signs and museum exhibits aren't the only place you'll see these sorts of miscommunications. Shopping malls are littered with clothes reading everything from 'Carpetbag in things I hoped you packed your STTW' on casual lounge wear to 'What the F?' on more formal business attire! I think my personal favorite was a sign warning passerby's not to walk on the grass, but instead of saying, 'stay off the grass,' it read, 'Please do not trample.'

choices.text: I'm in for a laugh. Show me some more signs!
Rules noted. I'll make sure not to spit at anything I see, and I don't have a flash lamp anyways; I'm also the quictest of folk, so all rules will be followed!
This is too much. Take me outta here!

1112000.content: As a small island nation with a population around three times that of Utah, TaiWan is extremely developed. TaiBei in particular is a massive city, with an outrageously high population density. Because of the constraint on open development space in TaiWan, much of TaiWan looks like this, with roads surrounded by highrises so tall you can barely see the sky.

choices.text: Go towards that tower in the background.
Stroll around the city for a bit.
What do the plants look like in a city this big?

1112100.content: The architecture in TaiWan is stunning, featuring a sleek modern style with elements of classic architectural influence. Wherever you look, you're sure to see at least a handful of unique and stylish buildings. Here's one of my personal favorites!

choices.text: Ok. Now let's get to the tower.
I'd like to see some more weird buildings!
What's the city look like at night?

1112110.content: Also lovingly referred to as the To-Go Box tower, architects constructed the TaiBei 101 to look like stacks of ancient money boxes. The 101 has some of the fastest elevators in the world to make the ascent up its 101 floors much more manageable, and over the years these elevators have gone through numerous cables. In the spirit of environmental mindfulness, the front of the tower features a metal sculpture, an 'embryo' born from these used cables.

choices.text: Let's head to the top!
I'm tired of the city. Let's see some wild life.
Let's see another part of TaiBei.

1112120.content: Companies such as MicroStar International have garnered TaiWan a well-earned place a the forefront of the computer industry, and TaiWan has been well known for it's technological prowess. It just so happens that this smiley face-looking shopping mall is home to one of TaiWan's largest tech centers. Inside, you'll find floor after floor of electronic sales, computer stores, lens and optics vendors, as well as a convenient food court on the first floor.

choices.text: Cool! What about more suburban architecture?
Show me some animal life
I'd like to see more of the city.

1112200.content: Here, you can see a few of the mopeds so famous and overwhelmingly popular in TaiWan. The amazing gas mileage and cheap costs of the mopeds makes them extremely convenient for city use, and the small size makes it easy to snag a parking spot wherever you go.

choices.text: Show me more bikes!
Is it just me, or is it starting to get dark?
Let's head back to the suburbs.

1112210.content: The first picture couldn't really ever portray just how popular the bikes and mopeds are in TaiWan, and this one can't either. But, at any rate, here are some more bikes!

choices.text: Let's see other modes of transportation

1112211.content: A TaiWanese victory train! The rail system in TaiBei is absurdly convenient, with enough trains on most of the routes so you never have to wait more than a few minutes to catch a ride, pricing fair enough so it's much more affordable than a car, or even a moped, and routes that cover the vast majority of anywhere you could need to go.

choices.text: Follow the train.
Take me somewhere warm.
Let's get some food!

1112220.content: If you haven't heard of them yet, the TaiWanese night markets are famous across the world for their large assortment of quality goods, both hand-crafted and mass produced, as well as food that's truly to die for. It looks like it's getting dark, so maybe this would be a good time to check out the world-renowned night markets?

choices.text: Sounds good, let's go shopping!
I'd rather see somewhere quieter.
Let's go to McDonalds!

1112230.content: Here's a plant found growing in DanShui. As a coastal suburb in a region spared from any harsh Winters, DanShui's plant life can be found easily year round. TaiWan as a whole is full of beautiful and memorable flora nad fauna, with beautiful plants like this around every corner. This particular flower just happens to be one of my personal favorites.

1120000.content: Taken at DanJiang University in DanShui, one of the many higher level educational institutes scatered across the suburbs of TaiWan. DanJiang University is located just a five minute walk from TaiWain's gorgeous waterline, and a ten minute train ride away from the famous ShiLin night market.

1310000.content:
As a traveler that likes to experience local culture everywhere I go, I'd like to start this with a full disclosure. I know it probably seems fairly tacky to go to another country, especially one with such refined and exquisite cuisine, and promptly proceed to track down the nearest Golden Arches. And so I feel obligated to inform you, the reader, that despite my love for experiencing new cuisines and expanding my culinary pallette, I still get a lot of joy out of seeing how my home culture translates to other countries. America is a big place, with a lot of variety from 

        Here, you can bear witness to one of the finest burgers ever crafted.


        This is without a doubt the liveliest shopping center I've ever been to. Aside from hundreds of small stores and outlets, plethoras of vendors bring hand made items to sell on the street, where you'll easily find whatever mouth-watering food, stylish clothes, or random knick-knacks you could ever possibly want. One of my favorite memories of TaiWan was just wandering around the Night Market for hours, browsing through the endless streets full of stores.

1213000.content: This giant ball of steel within the TaiBei 101 serves as a damper to protect the building from high wind and earthquakes.

choices.text: Cool! That's enough for me. Now let's see something more lively!
I heard the TaiBei 101 has a pretty gnarly mall...

1213200.content: That's right! The TaiBei 101 is home to a five story shopping mall that is directly adjacent to the tower. Myriad fashion and design stores can be found on the upper levels, while an expansive food court is located below. Parking is also available on the lowest levels for those with personal transportation.

choices.text: This talk of food courts has me feeling hungry. Let's head downstairs.
I'm ready to head to DanShui. Show me what it's got!

1213210.content: A glorious Big Mac, courteous of the TaiBei 101 McDonalds. As you can see from the image, the quality at this franchise is beyond exquisite. Note the perfect tecture on the bun, the righteous stacking of the patty. (Although you can't see it from the picture, I assure you, the taste was absolutely perfect. Here is my experience with it: After sitting down to enjoy my Big Mac with several friends, the first thing I noticed was the savory smell of the burger. Strong, noticeable, and yet not overwhelming. The aroma of McDonald's secret sauce, mixed with just a hint of relish and fresh fried patty left my mouth watering. As I picked up the burger, I noticed the flawless condition of the stack; it made me aware of just how much love must have gone into the construction of the burger so plainly sitting before me. My first bite of the burger confirmed all of my initial impressions. A rush of flavor unlike any I've ever experienced at any other McDonalds overwhelmed me, and I proceeded to ravenously devour my burger in silence, thoroughly enjoying the best Big Mac I've ever had. If you ever find yourself in the vicinity of TaiWan, I highly recommend swinging by the 101's food court just to sample this McDonalds.
